column2: NF, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been on Imuran for over 3 weeks now.  I am being treated for Seronegative Spondeloarthritis.  Basically I am HLA-B 27 + and my imune system is attacking my joints causing severe pain to the point that I almost couldn't walk.  I am 26 years old.  I started out on 50 mil and just increased to 100 mil.  When I started and increased I was extremely nauseated for the entire day and couldn't eat anything, but I never threw up or had diahrrea.  So far there is no pain and it seems to be working for me.  I go to run my labs in a few weeks and I am anxious to make sure that it is not affecting my kidney/ liver/ blood cells.  I can say though that the other side affects I seem to be having include sleepyness/ tiredness all the time and my teeth burn when I drink anything now which did not happen before.  Also I was severely constipated to the point of hurting at first, but I took a few stool softeners and got some relief and I have not had to take anymore as it seems to kind of be going away.  I will leave another review once I see if it's affecting my labs and still working for me.  Good luck and God Bless.

watchoutforthatdoc, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Do not mix Imuran(Azathioprine)with the gout drug Allopurinol. This drug combination will cause the Imuran to increase to toxic levels and shut down a functioning bone marrow system. My brilliant PCP did this and I ended up in the hospital at 10K a day. No one could figure it out, because doctors' are stupid. The pharmacy missed it, because CVS hits enter to bypass it's DUR in order to fill prescriptions quickly. This little adventure cost me over $10,000 in out of pocket costs. It was not my mistake and I have to come up with the 10K. Good luck out there, and be careful.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I took Imuran for 12 years for Crohns Disease, when I first started taking it the only bad side effect was lymphoma and thinning hair.  Well 5 yrs ago I was diagnoised with skin cancer. Still to this day I am having several lesions of the skin cancer removed from my body.  Approx. 20-25 lesions removed so far.  The Dr. told me it will never go away but will slow down, after 5 years it hasn't slowed down so when will it ?? Does anyone know that answer???  I look like a walking brown spot, the brown spots cover my entire body along with the lesions.  This really bothers me I will not wear shorts out in public because of the skin problem on my legs.  Honestly I feel more research needs to be done before they release medications.  Because now I will have saqmous cell cancer removed from my body for the rest of my life.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with Crohn's in 1975 and took azulfadine until 2002 when I had a resection.  Went on pentasa but had flareup and was put on imuran- 150mg in 2003.  It was very effective until this year when I am starting to have active Crohn's again and am moving on to a biologic.  After the resection I began to exercise and get into shape and felt better than I have ever felt.  I was also able to reduce my stress level and eat right and get plenty of rest.  All the side effects listed for this drug scared the hell out of me.  I had no side affects on imuran and felt better than I had ever felt.

column2: happy2balive, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have dermatomyositis, after having "serious" side effects after 5 years on methotrexate, was put on Imuran. Typical side effects at first, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, hair loss, none of which were as severe as when first put on methotrexate. It has kepp my disease under control and my CPK numbers remain in the normal range. Have never attained remission, also on prednisone, but have been able to lower that dose which is great because my bones have suffered from the steriod use. Already have had to have two total hip replacements from the prednisone, constant broken bones for no reason except bones are so weak. My doctor says, the side effects of the methotrexate and Imuran are as bad if not worse than the disease itself, but better than not being able to move at all from the muscle disease. Still have to take two kinds of pain meds. Also have lung issues, whether from the meds or the muscle disease, not sure which.

column2: Valerie, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I purchased 180 quantity bottle and took 1 50mg Imuran 2x daily for 9 days. Negative effects of rash on arms one day and legs the following day, severe upper arm muscle pain in mornings.

I only experienced negative side effects--the most bothersome to me: a tumor on my face, that had to be removed--because of Imuran's risk of skin cancer--leaving a very large scar on my face. I also had bad acne, but was also on prednisone and asacol. The cystic acne left scars, which goes nice with the large scar I have from the tumor--I had perfect skin before; now my skin looks horrible. It gave me yellow skin (possible liver damage). I was sick the whole time I was on it, kept getting infections, and was always vomiting. I felt unusually weak and tired, and I know it wasn't my disease--I felt normal when I stopped taking Imuran. It also gave me warts. I wouldn't recommend using this if you're young. This drug, along with prednisone, really destroyed my self-esteem and ruined my life. It has serious risks--leukemia, lymphoma, and skin cancer. Your doctor's supposed to monitor you closely while you're on it; mine didn't. If you do use it, you absolutely have to have a competent doctor. If not, Crohn's will be the least of your worries. The Mayo Clinic even points out that because the way Imuran works some side effects might not be noticed until years after using it. "Also, because of the way this medicine acts on the body, there is a chance that it might cause other unwanted effects that may not occur until months or years after the medicine is used. These delayed effects may include certain types of cancer, such as leukemia, lymphoma, or skin cancer. However, the risk of cancer seems to be lower in people taking azathioprine for arthritis."[1] Your doctor should definitely tell you that before using it--mine didn't--and if yours doesn't, find a new doctor; that's their job; they're actually legally required to tell you that; they know nothing will happen to them if they don't though. So the ones that just care about money, they won't. [1]http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/drug-info rmation/DR601561

All because I was not tested for compatability my liver did not matabolize the drug and I overdosed on it even though my dose was very small  Get the blood test.  Don't be that 1 in million person

column2: mzmuskratt@aol.com, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed 50 mg in the am and pm. By the second dose, I was experiencing nausea. Second day: experiencing severe nausea and dry heaves. Third day: excruciating constant headaches.  By the forth day, I could not walk alone and all the other symptoms remained as well. I discontinued the medication upon doctor's orders. It took another five days to semi-recover from the symptoms. I still am having some mental comprehension issues (9 days after discontinuing Imuran) and my Lupus symptoms are increasing since my immune system is no longer suppressed (fever, rash, pain, fatigue, etc).

column2: Midwest UC Warrior, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Medication takes several months for full effectiveness, but has been very effective in maintaining remission. The upside: I now take meds once/day (rather than Asacol 3x/day), and I have experienced no side effects - my bloodwork always looks very good. The downside: Bloodwork every 3 months to monitor liver function. When the work schedule is hectic it is a nuisance to have to work in a trip to the lab, but it is certainly worth it to maintain remission. Also,the blood test that is needed to thoroughly check Imuran levels can only be done by a lab in California, and is not covered by my insurance (but I've only had to do that once).

column2: sboreham1@verizon.net, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more
column9: I have taken Imuran for 30 years for two kidney transplants. I have had skin cancers that go away and reappear. The worst side effect is it is destroying my liver...my liver enzymes are off the charts and the doctors can't find a comparable drug that is less dehabilitating to the liver.

column2: 55-64 Female  (Patient)
column9: This medicine took months to improve my Ulcerative Colitis and I'm still not in remission.  So my doctor had me go up to 150 mg. and now my hair is falling out.

column2: duffer, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I've been using this drug for about 20 years and it has been extemely effective in controlling my Crohn's disease. I've had no side effects and no reoccurances since I been on this drug. I have my blood checked every 3 months, no problems.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug worked well for me in relieving my Crohn's disease for a couple of years. The side effects were minimal, though I did catch colds much more easily and did get a case of chicken pox, despite having them previously. Unfortunately, it has stopped working as well for me. We don't know if we should edge up the dose, carefully, because of previous low white blood count on 6-MP or if it is time to move to Remicade or another treatment.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I still had a UC flare up in spite of increased dose.  Recently had B-12 and folate anemia, but seems to have cleared up with prescription pre-natal vitamins (not for pregnancy).  Recently learned that my doctor was suprised to find out that brand name drug "Imuran" was substituted with generic azathioprine and she said that they are different in the way the dosages are prescribed and that could explain why it wasn't working (my dose was metabolized too well by my body and thus was not therapeutic) for the past year.  She and I will begin adjusting my dose accordingly now, knowing that I'm taking azathioprine instead.  Be sure your doctor knows if your pharmacy/insurance substitutes generic for Imuran.  I'm also going to try to get off this med soon after the flare is under control so that my husband and I can start a family.  Not allowed to take it while pregnant or nursing.
